context: Wonderful article, but "Francis Scott Key awoke aboard a British warship after watching the terrifying 25-hour bombardment of Fort McHenry".. no.  He and an American Colonel traveled on their own ship under truce to meet the British fleet, and had been on a British ship the prior evening negotiating a prisoner release.  They dined with the British commander and then retired back to their ship but were not allowed to depart the fleet as the British were concerned they knew position information, etc.   Thus, he watched the long bombardment from the American ship.
Now go ask some of the young people when the war of 1812 started and you'll be amazed by the number of wrong answers you'll get.

What isn't told here but should:

The British commander had demanded an American surrender, and offered all the Americans would have to do to stop the attack was to lower their flag.  In defiance the Americans were determined the flag wouldn't be lowered.  During the engagement, the frustrated British commander ordered all guns to target the flag to take it down by force, and they succeeded.  The response by the American forces is what I wish to note.

It is said that men ran to re-secure the flag only to get blown to bits.  Each time the flag faltered men rushed to support it.  Each group knew their fate if they did.  By morning's light the flag still flew.  At its base a very high price.  It stood not on its own but rather because it was planted and held firm by a pile of corpses.  It stood because defiant men gave their lives to assure the British never saw the flag lowered.
